channel.title: This American Life
channel.description: This American Life is a weekly public radio show, heard by 2.2 million people on more than 500 stations. Another 2.5 million people download the weekly podcast. It is hosted by Ira Glass, produced in collaboration with Chicago Public Media, delivered to stations by PRX The Public Radio Exchange, and has won all of the major broadcasting awards.
channel.itunes:author: This American Life
channel.itunes:subtitle: This American Life is a weekly public radio show, heard by 2.2 million people on more than 500 stations. Another 2.5 million people download the weekly podcast. It is hosted by Ira Glass, produced in collaboration with Chicago Public Media, delivered to s

item.title: 668: The Long Fuse
item.description: People tossing words out into the world impulsively. And how they ignite and burn. Over decades.
item.itunes:author: This American Life
item.itunes:subtitle: People tossing words out into the world impulsively. And how they ignite and burn. Over decades.
item.itunes:summary: People tossing words out into the world impulsively. And how they ignite and burn. Over decades.
item.dc:creator: This American Life

item.title: 486: Valentine’s Day
item.description: Love makes us do crazy things. But usually not this crazy. This week for Valentine's Day we have stories of people going to extremes to find and pursue their one true love.
item.itunes:author: This American Life
item.itunes:subtitle: A couple decides to sleep with other people before they tie the knot. Plus, more stories of love making us do crazy things.
item.itunes:summary: Love makes us do crazy things. But usually not this crazy. This week for Valentine's Day we have stories of people going to extremes to find and pursue their one true love.
item.dc:creator: This American Life

item.title: 667: Wartime Radio
item.description: Intimate and personal dispatches from two very different battlefields: A small town in the Syrian war. And the U.S. opioid epidemic. Each came from a DIY radio outfit. (Okay, one’s a podcast.)
item.itunes:author: This American Life
item.itunes:subtitle: Intimate and personal dispatches from two very different battlefields.
item.itunes:summary: Intimate and personal dispatches from two very different battlefields: A small town in the Syrian war. And the U.S. opioid epidemic. Each came from a DIY radio outfit. (Okay, one’s a podcast.)
item.dc:creator: This American Life

item.title: 638: Rom-Com
item.description: The one thing you know for sure when you're watching a romantic comedy is that it's going to turn out okay in the end. When you're living one? Not so much. This week, stories that unfold like rom-coms.
item.itunes:author: This American Life
item.itunes:subtitle: Stories about surviving the mishaps of love.
item.itunes:summary: The one thing you know for sure when you're watching a romantic comedy is that it's going to turn out okay in the end. When you're living one? Not so much. This week, stories that unfold like rom-coms.
item.dc:creator: This American Life

item.title: 666: The Theme That Shall Not Be Named
item.description: Satan! In his many surprising manifestations, all around us.
item.itunes:author: This American Life
item.itunes:subtitle: Satan! In his many surprising manifestations, all around us.
item.itunes:summary: Satan! In his many surprising manifestations, all around us.
item.dc:creator: This American Life

item.title: 665: Before Things Went to Hell
item.description: We revisit those moments of calm before the storm, when things could have gone very differently, but instead, they went to hell.
item.itunes:author: This American Life
item.itunes:subtitle: Revisiting those moments of calm before the storm.
item.itunes:summary: We revisit those moments of calm before the storm, when things could have gone very differently, but instead, they went to hell.
item.dc:creator: This American Life

item.title: 664: The Room of Requirement
item.description: Libraries aren't just for books. They're often spaces that transform into what you need them to be: a classroom, a cyber café, a place to find answers, a quiet spot to be alone. It's actually kind of magical. This week, we have stories of people who roam the stacks and find unexpected things that just happen to be exactly what they required.
item.itunes:author: This American Life
item.itunes:subtitle: Stories of people who roam the stacks and find unexpected things that just happen to be exactly what they required.
item.itunes:summary: Libraries aren't just for books. They're often spaces that transform into what you need them to be: a classroom, a cyber café, a place to find answers, a quiet spot to be alone. It's actually kind of magical. This week, we have stories of people who roam the stacks and find unexpected things that just happen to be exactly what they required.
item.dc:creator: This American Life

item.title: 663: How I Read It
item.description: Documents you don't normally think of, showing you things you didn't expect.
item.itunes:author: This American Life
item.itunes:subtitle: Documents you don't normally think of, showing you things you didn't expect.
item.itunes:summary: Documents you don't normally think of, showing you things you didn't expect.
item.dc:creator: This American Life

item.title: 662: Where There Is a Will
item.description: Stories of people who believe there is always a way. And also those who don’t.
item.itunes:author: This American Life
item.itunes:subtitle: Stories of people who believe there is always a way. And also those who don’t.
item.itunes:summary: Stories of people who believe there is always a way. And also those who don’t.
item.dc:creator: This American Life

item.title: 661: But That's What Happened
item.description: Stories of women in unsettling situations. When they try to explain what’s wrong, they’re told that they don’t understand—that there’s nothing unsettling about it.
item.itunes:author: This American Life
item.itunes:subtitle: Stories of women in unsettling situations, who are told that there’s nothing unsettling at all.
item.itunes:summary: Stories of women in unsettling situations. When they try to explain what’s wrong, they’re told that they don’t understand—that there’s nothing unsettling about it.
item.dc:creator: This American Life
